annotations.shortDefinition: A postal address
annotations.definition: There is a variety of postal address formats defined around the world. This format defines a superset that is the basis for addresses all around the world
annotations.comment: Note: address is for postal addresses, not physical locations
annotations.requirements: Need to be able to record postal addresses, along with notes about their use

binding.name: AddressUse
binding.definition: The use of an address

code.definition: A communication address at a home
An office address. First choice for business related contacts during business hours
A temporary address. The period can provide more detailed information
This address is no longer in use (or was never correct, but retained for records)

annotation.definition: Identifies the intended purpose of this address
annotation.comment: This is labelled as "Is Modifier" because applications should not mistake a temporary or old address etc for a current/permanent one. Applications can assume that an address is not temporary or old unless it explicitly says that it is
annotation.requirements: Allows an appropriate address to be chosen from a list of many
annotation.committeeNotes: Is it outside the 80% for this to repeat?

annotation.definition: A full text representation of the address
annotation.comment: Can provide both a text representation and parts
annotation.requirements: A renderable, unencoded form

annotation.definition: A line of an address (typically used for street names & numbers, unit details, delivery hints, etc.) .
The name of the city, town, village or other community or delivery centre.
Sub-unit of a country with limited sovereignty in a federally organized country. A code may be used if codes are in common use (i.e. US 2 letter state codes).
A postal code designating a region defined by the postal service.
Country. ISO 3166 3 letter codes can be used in place of a full country name.

annotation.shortDefinition: Time period when address was/is in use
annotation.definition: Time period when address was/is in use
annotation.requirements: Allows addresses to be placed in historical context

annotations.definition: A constrained type based on Quantity

detail.name: Age
detail.human: The unit must be an amount of time and a UCUM unit must be provided, and the value must be positive

annotations.shortDefinition: Content in a format defined elsewhere
annotations.definition: For referring to data content defined in other formats.
annotations.requirements: Many models need to include data defined in other specifications that is complex and opaque to the healthcare model. This includes documents, media recordings, structured data, etc.

binding.name: MimeType
binding.definition: The mime type of an attachment

binding.name: Language
binding.definition: A human language

annotation.shortDefinition: Mime type of the content, with charset etc.
annotation.definition: Identifies the type of the data in the attachment and allows a method to be chosen to interpret or render the data. Includes mime type parameters such as charset where appropriate
annotation.requirements: Processors of the data need to be able to tell what the data is

annotation.definition: The human language of the content. The value can be any valid value according to BCP 47
annotation.requirements: Users need to be able to pick between the languages in a set of attachments

annotation.definition: The actual data of the attachment - a sequence of bytes. In XML, represented using base64
annotation.comment: The base64-encoded data must be expressed in the same character set as the base resource XML
annotation.requirements: The data needs to able to be transmitted inline
annotation.todo: Should this be handled by an extension? How common is it?

annotation.shortDefinition: Uri where the data can be found
annotation.definition: An alternative location where the data can be accessed
annotation.comment: If both data and url are provided, the url must point to the same content as the data contains. Urls may be relative references or may be made to transient locations such as a wrapping envelope using cid: though this has ramifications for using signatures. If a URL is provided, it must resolve to actual data.
annotation.requirements: The data needs to be transmitted by reference
annotation.todo: Sort out relative URL references

annotation.shortDefinition: Number of bytes of content (if url provided)
annotation.definition: The number of bytes of data that make up this attachment.
annotation.comment: The number of bytes is redundant if the data is provided as a base64binary, but is useful if the data is provided as a url reference
annotation.requirements: Representing the size allows applications to determine whether they should fetch the content automatically in advance, or refuse to fetch it at all

annotation.definition: The calculated hash of the data using SHA-1. Represented using base64
annotation.requirements: Included so that applications can verify that the contents of a location have not changed and also so that a signature of the xml content can implicitly sign the content of an image without having to include the data in the instance or reference the url in the signature

annotation.shortDefinition: Label to display in place of the data
annotation.definition: A label or set of text to display in place of the data
annotation.requirements: Applications need a label to display to a human user in place of the actual data if the data cannot be rendered or perceived by the viewer.

annotations.shortDefinition: Code from list of choices
annotations.definition: A code taken from a short list of codes that are not defined in a formal code system
annotations.comment: Choice is generally used for things like pain scales, questionnaires or formally defined assessment indexes. The possible codes may be ordered with some arbitrarily defined scale. Choice does not fit all assessment scales - the more combinatorial the value is, the less likely that Choice will be an appropriate data type
annotations.requirements: Questionnaires and the like - assessment scales. There's no formal terminology underlying them, yet the possible choices affect the interpretation of the code. Because the choice can be quite dynamic, the price of setting up formal infrastructure to carry the choices out of band is expensive

annotations.definition: A nested type in Choice: A list of possible values for the code

annotation.definition: A possible code or value that the user could have chosen
annotation.requirements: Need to know the possible codes the user could have chosen

annotation.definition: A set of words associated with the code to give it meaning and displayed to the user
annotation.comment: The code itself may convey sufficient meaning. If there aren't both a code and a display provided, the display string is presumed to be the code.
annotation.requirements: Sometimes the codes have associated words that give it more meaning

annotation.definition: The code or value that the user selected from the list of possible codes
annotation.comment: The "code" might be a numerical choice in a pain scale, for instance, 1 where the choices are 1-5 with associated words for severity of pain

annotation.definition: A list of possible values for the code
annotation.requirements: Need to know the possible codes the user could have chosen
annotation.rimMapping: Expansion of CD.valueSet to list of CDs

annotation.shortDefinition: If order of the values has meaning
annotation.definition: Whether the order of the values has an assigned meaning
annotation.requirements: The Choice may come from an ordered scale such as a pain scale or a an assessment scale, or it may be just a random set of choices that have no particular order

annotations.shortDefinition: Concept - reference to a terminology or just text
annotations.definition: A concept that may be defined by a formal reference to a terminology or ontology or may be provided by text
annotations.comment: Not all terminology uses fit this general pattern. In some cases, models should not use CodeableConcept and use Coding directly and provide their own structure for managing text, codings, translations and the relationship between elements and pre- and post-coordination
annotations.requirements: This is a common pattern in healthcare - a concept that may be defined by one or more codes from formal definitions including LOINC and SNOMED-CT, and/or defined by the provision of text that captures a human sense of the concept

annotation.shortDefinition: Code defined by a terminology system
annotation.definition: A reference to a code defined by a terminology system
annotation.comment: Codes may defined very casually in enumerations, or code lists, up to very formal definitions such as SNOMED-CT - see the v3 core principles for more information. Ordering of codings is undefined and must not be used to infer meaning.
annotation.requirements: Allows for translations and alternate encodings within a code system. Also supports communication of the same instance to systems requiring different encodings.

annotation.shortDefinition: Plain text representation of the concept
annotation.definition: A human language representation of the concept as seen/selected/uttered by the user who entered the data and/or which represents the intended meaning of the user or concept
annotation.comment: Very often the text is the same as a displayName of one of the codings
annotation.requirements: The codes from the terminologies do not always capture the correct meaning with all the nuances of the human, or sometimes there is no appropriate code at all. In these cases, the text is used to capture the full meaning of the source

annotation.shortDefinition: Which code was chosen directly by the user
annotation.definition: Indicates which of the codes in the codings was chosen by a user, if one was chosen directly
annotation.requirements: Where a user picks an actual code directly, it is useful to note that this is the primary input. It's also the most appropriate starting point for new translations (unless re-coding directly from 'text').
annotation.rimMapping: special("The id assigned to the coding that corresponds to the root code of the CD")

invariant.human: If a primary reference is present, it must point to one of the codings

annotations.shortDefinition: A reference to a code defined by a terminology system
annotations.definition: A reference to a code defined by a terminology system
annotations.comment: Codes may defined very casually in enumerations or code lists, up to very formal definitions such as SNOMED-CT - see the v3 core principles for more information
annotations.requirements: Referring to codes is a ubiquitous task in healthcare models

annotation.definition: The identification of the system that defines the meaning of the symbol in the code. Can be a simple list of enumerations, a list of codes with meanings or all the way to a complex semantic web such as SNOMED-CT, whether classification, terminology, or ontology
annotation.comment: The identity is a uri. It may be an OID or a UUID, which must be references to the HL7 OID registry, or a URI which either comes from HL7's list of FHIR defined special URIs or from some system defined elsewhere, in which case the URI should de-reference to establish the system unambiguously
annotation.requirements: Need to be unambiguous about the source of the definition of the symbol

annotation.shortDefinition: Symbol in syntax defined by the system
annotation.definition: A symbol in syntax defined by the system. The symbol may be a predefined code or an expression in a syntax defined by the coding system
annotation.requirements: Need to refer to a particular code in the system

annotation.definition: A representation of the meaning of the code in the system, following the rules laid out by the system.
annotation.requirements: Need to be able to carry a human readable meaning of the code for readers that do not recognise the system

annotations.shortDefinition: All kinds of technology mediated contact details for a person or organisation, including telephone, email, etc.
annotations.definition: All kinds of technology mediated contact details for a person or organisation, including telephone, email, etc.
annotations.requirements: Need to track phone, fax, mobile, sms numbers, email addresses, twitter tags, etc.

binding.name: ContactSystem
binding.definition: What kind of contact this is

code.definition: The value is a telephone number used for voice calls. Use of full international numbers starting with + is recommended to enable automatic dialing support but not required.
The value is a fax machine. Use of full international numbers starting with + is recommended to enable automatic dialing support but not required.
The value is an email address
The value is a url. This is intended for various personal contacts including blogs, Twitter, Facebook, etc. Do not use for email addresses

binding.name: ContactUse
binding.definition: How to use this address

code.definition: A communication contact at a home; attempted contacts for business purposes might intrude privacy and chances are one will contact family or other household members instead of the person one wishes to call. Typically used with urgent cases, or if no other contacts are available.
An office contact. First choice for business related contacts during business hours.
A temporary contact. The period can provide more detailed information.
This contact is no longer in use (or was never correct, but retained for records)
A telecommunication device that moves and stays with its owner. May have characteristics of all other use codes, suitable for urgent matters, not the first choice for routine business

annotation.shortDefinition: What kind of contact this is
annotation.definition: What kind of contact this is - what communications system is required to make use of the contact
The actual contact details, in a form that is meaningful to the designated communication system (i.e. phone number or email address).
annotation.comment: additional out of band data such as extensions, or notes about use of the contact are sometimes included in the value
annotation.requirements: Need to support legacy numbers that are not in a tightly controlled format

annotation.definition: Identifies the context for the address
annotation.comment: This is labelled as "Is Modifier" because applications should not mistake a temporary or old contact etc for a current/permanent one. Applications can assume that a contact is not temporary or old unless it explicitly says that it is
annotation.requirements: Need to track the way a person uses this contact, so a user can choose which is appropriate for their purpose

annotation.shortDefinition: Time period when the contact was/is in use
annotation.definition: Time period when the contact was/is in use

invariant.human: A system is required if a value is provided.

annotations.definition: A constrained type based on Quantity

detail.name: Count
detail.human: The value must a whole number and the UCUM unit must be "1"

annotations.definition: A constrained type based on Quantity

detail.name: Distance
detail.human: The unit must be an amount of length and a UCUM unit must be provided.

annotations.definition: A constrained type based on Quantity

detail.name: Duration
detail.human: The unit must be an amount of time and a UCUM unit must be provided.

annotations.shortDefinition: Basetype for all composite-typed elements

annotations.definition: Optional Extensions Element - found in all resources
annotations.requirements: The ability to add extensions in a structured way is what keeps FHIR resources simple

annotation.shortDefinition: identifies the meaning of the extension
annotation.definition: Source of the definition for the extension code - a logical name or a URL
annotation.comment: The definition may point directly to a computable or human readable definition of the extensibility codes, or it may be a logical URI as declared in some other specification. The definition should be version specific. This will ideally be the URI for the Resource Profile defining the extension, with the code for the extension after a #

annotation.definition: This value should be set to true if the value of the extension qualifies or negates data in other content
annotation.comment: If this element is set to true, then the containing resource/element and its children are only safe to process if the reader understands this extension, and knows what the potential impact is. This does not mean that the application is required to do anything with the value, it is just not permitted to act inappropriately for any possible value in the element

annotation.definition: Value of extension - may be a resource or one of a constrained set of the data types (see Extensibility in the spec for list)

invariant.human: No extensions on isModifier
No extensions on url

annotations.shortDefinition: Name of a human
annotations.definition: A human's name with the ability to identify parts and usage
annotations.comment: Names may be changed, or repudiated, or people may have different names in different contexts. Names may be divided into parts of different type that have variable significance depending on context, though the division into parts does not always matter. With personal names, the different parts may or may not be imbued with some implicit meaning; various cultures associate different importance with the name parts, and the degree to which systems must care about name parts around the world varies widely.
annotations.requirements: Need to be able to record names, along with notes about their use

binding.name: NameUse
binding.definition: The use of a human name

code.definition: Known as/conventional/the one you normally use
The formal name as registered in an official (government) registry, but which name might not be commonly used. May be called "legal name".
A temporary name. A name valid time can provide more detailed information. This may also be used for temporary names assigned at birth or in emergency situations.
A name that is used to address the person in an informal manner, but is not part of their formal or usual name
Anonymous assigned name, alias, or pseudonym (used to protect a person's identity for privacy reasons)
This name is no longer in use (or was never correct, but retained for records)

A name used prior to marriage. Marriage naming customs vary greatly around the world. This name use is for use by applications that collect and store "maiden" names. Though the concept of maiden name is often gender specific, the use of this term is not gender specific. The use of this term does not imply any particular history for a person's name, nor should the maiden name be determined algorithmically.

annotation.definition: Identifies the purpose for this name
annotation.comment: This is labelled as "Is Modifier" because applications should not mistake a temporary or old name etc for a current/permanent one. Applications can assume that a name is not temporary or old unless it explicitly says that it is
annotation.requirements: Allows the appropriate name for a particular context of use to be selected from among a set of names

annotation.shortDefinition: Text representation of the full name
annotation.definition: A full text representation of the name
annotation.comment: Can provide both a text representation and structured parts.
annotation.requirements: A renderable, unencoded form

annotation.definition: Family name, this is the name that links to the genealogy. In some cultures (e.g. Eritrea) the family name of a son is the first name of his father.
annotation.comment: family name is allowed to repeat. A single family name with spaces is equivalent to multiple family names with the same values

annotation.shortDefinition: Given names (not always 'first'). Includes middle names
annotation.definition: Given name. NOTE: Not to be called "first name" since given names do not always come first.

annotation.shortDefinition: Parts that come before the name
annotation.definition: Part of the name that is acquired as a title due to academic, legal, employment or nobility status, etc. and that comes at the start of the name

annotation.shortDefinition: Parts that come after the name
annotation.definition: Part of the name that is acquired as a title due to academic, legal, employment or nobility status, etc. and that comes at the end of the name

annotation.shortDefinition: Time period when name was/is in use
annotation.definition: Indicates the period of time when this name was valid for the named person.
annotation.requirements: Allows names to be placed in historical context

annotations.shortDefinition: An identifier intended for computation
annotations.definition: A technical identifier - identifies some entity uniquely and unambiguously
annotations.comment: the Identifier class is a little looser than II because it allows URIs as well as registered OIDs or GUIDs
annotations.requirements: Need to be able to identify things with confidence and be sure that the identification is not subject to misinterpretation

binding.name: IdentifierUse
binding.definition: Identifies the use for this identifier, if known

code.definition: the identifier recommended for display and use in real-world interactions
the identifier considered to be most trusted for the identification of this item
A temporary identifier

annotation.definition: Identifies the use for this identifier, if known
annotation.comment: This is labelled as "Is Modifier" because applications should not mistake a temporary id for a permanent one. Applications can assume that an identifier is not temporary unless it explicitly says that it is
annotation.requirements: Allows the appropriate identifier for a particular context of use to be selected from among a set of identifiers

annotation.definition: A label for the identifier that can be displayed to a human so they can recognise the identifier
annotation.requirements: Allows humans to make use of identifiers when the identifier system is not known

annotation.definition: Establishes the namespace in which set of possible id values is unique.
annotation.requirements: There are many sequences of identifiers. To perform matching, we need to know what sequence we're dealing with.

annotation.definition: The portion of the identifier typically displayed to the user and which is unique within the context of the system.
annotation.comment: if the key value is actually a full uri, then the system is urn:ietf:rfc:3986
annotation.rimMapping: II.extension or II.root if system indicates OID or GUID

annotation.shortDefinition: Time period when id was valid for use
annotation.definition: Time period during which identifier was valid for use

annotation.shortDefinition: Organisation that issued id (may be just text)
annotation.definition: Organisation that issued/manages the identifier
annotation.comment: The reference may be just a text description of the assigner

annotations.definition: A constrained type based on Quantity

detail.name: Money
detail.human: The unit must be a currency and the code must from ISO 4217 (system = "urn:std:iso:4217")

annotations.shortDefinition: A human readable formatted text, including images
annotations.definition: A human readable formatted text, including images

binding.name: NarrativeStatus
binding.definition: The status of a resource narrative

code.definition: The contents of the narrative are entirely generated from the structured data in the resource.
The contents of the narrative are entirely generated from the structured data in the resource and some of the content is generated from extensions
The contents of the narrative contain additional information not found in the structured data
the contents of the narrative are some equivalent of "No human readable text provided for this resource"

annotation.definition: The status of the narrative - whether it's entirely generated (from just the defined data or the extensions too), or whether a human authored it and it may contain additional data
The actual narrative content, a stripped down version of XHTML
annotation.comment: The contents of the html element are an XHTML fragment containing only the basic html formatting elements described in chapters 7-11 and 15 of the HTML 4.0 standard, <a> elements (either name or href), images and internally contained stylesheets. The XHTML content may not contain a head, a body, external stylesheet references, scripts, forms, base/link/xlink, frames, iframes and objects.

annotations.shortDefinition: Time range defined by start and end time
annotations.definition: A time period defined by a start and end time.
annotations.comment: Not a duration - that's a measure of time (a separate type), but a duration that occurs at a fixed value of time. A Period specifies a range of time; the context of use will specify whether the entire range applies (e.g. "the patient was an inpatient of the hospital for this time range") or one value from the range applies (e.g. "give to the patient between these two times"). If a duration might be required, specify the type as Interval|Duration
annotations.rimMapping: IVL<TS>[lowClosed="true" and highClosed="true"] or URG<TS>[lowClosed="true" and highClosed="true"]

annotation.definition: The start of the period. The boundary is inclusive.
annotation.comment: If the low element is missing, the meaning is that the low boundary is not known.

annotation.shortDefinition: The end of the period, if not ongoing
annotation.definition: The end of the period. If the high is missing, it means that the period is ongoing
annotation.comment: The high value includes any matching date/time. i.e. 2012-02-03T10:00:00 is in a period that has a end value of 2012-02-03

annotations.shortDefinition: A measured or measurable amount
annotations.definition: A measured amount (or an amount that can potentially be measured). Note that measured amounts include amounts that are not precisely quantified, including amounts involving arbitrary units and floating currencies
annotations.comment: The context of use may frequently define what kind of quantity this is and therefore what kind of units can be used. The context of use may also restrict the values for status
annotations.requirements: Need to able to capture all sorts of measured values, even if the measured value are not precisely quantified. Values include exact measures such as 3.51g, customary units such as 3 tablets, currencies such as $100.32USD
annotations.rimMapping: PQ, IVL<PQ>, MO, CO, depending on the values

binding.name: QuantityCompararator
binding.definition: how the Quantity should be understood and represented

code.definition: The actual value is less than the given value
The actual value is less than or equal to the given value
The actual value is greater than or equal to the given value
The actual value is greater than the given value

annotation.definition: The value of the measured amount. The value includes an implicit precision in the presentation of the value
annotation.comment: The implicit precision should always be honored. Currency has its own rules for handling precision
annotation.requirements: Precision is handled implicitly in almost all cases of measurement
annotation.rimMapping: PQ.value, CO.value, MO.value, IVL.high or IVL.low depending on the value

annotation.shortDefinition: Relationship of stated value to actual value
annotation.definition: How the value should be understood and represented - whether the actual value is greater or less than the stated value due to measurement issues. E.g. if the comparator is "<" , then the real value is < stated value
annotation.comment: This is labelled as "Is Modifier" because the comparator modifies the interpretation of the value significantly. If there is no comparator, then there is no impact
annotation.requirements: Need a framework for handling measures where the value is <5ug/L or >400mg/L due to the limitations of measuring methodology.

annotation.definition: A human readable form of the units
annotation.requirements: There are lots of representations for the units and in many contexts, particular representations are fixed and required. i.e. mcg for micrograms and not ug

annotation.shortDefinition: System that defines coded unit form
annotation.definition: The identification of the system that provides the coded form of the unit
annotation.requirements: Need to know the system that defines the coded form of the unit

annotation.definition: A computer processable form of the units in some unit representation system
annotation.comment:
The preferred system is UCUM, but SNOMED-CT can also be used (for customary units) or ISO 4217 for currency.
The context of use may additionally require a code from a particular system (Unless the Quantity element has a dataAbsentReason flag)
annotation.requirements: Need a computable form of the units that is fixed across all forms. UCUM provides this for quantities, but SNOMED-CT provides many arbitrary units of interest

invariant.human: If a code for the units is present, the system must also be present

annotations.shortDefinition: Set of values bounded by low and high
annotations.definition: A set of ordered Quantities defined by a low and high limit.
annotations.comment: The stated low and high value are assumed to have arbitrarily high precision when it comes to determining which values are in the range. i.e. 1.99 is not in the range 2 -> 3
annotations.requirements: Need to be able to specify ranges of values or time periods

annotation.definition: The low limit. The boundary is inclusive.
annotation.comment: If the low element is missing, the meaning is that the low boundary is not known.

annotation.definition: The high limit. The boundary is inclusive.
annotation.comment: If the high element is missing, the meaning is that the high boundary is not known.

invariant.human: Quantity values cannot have a range when used in a Range

annotations.shortDefinition: A ratio of two Quantity values - a numerator and a denominator
annotations.definition: A ratio of two Quantity values - a numerator and a denominator.
annotations.requirements: Need to able to capture ratios for some measurements (titers) and some rates (costs)

annotation.definition: The numerator
The denominator

annotations.shortDefinition: A reference from one resource to another
annotations.definition: A reference from one resource to another
annotations.rimMapping: The target of a resource reference is a RIM entry point (Act, Role, or Entity)

annotation.definition: The name of one of the resource types defined in this specification to identify the type of the resource being referenced
annotation.comment: Whether or not the type of the resource reference is fixed for a particular element, the reference includes the resource type

annotation.shortDefinition: Relative, internal or absolute URL reference
annotation.definition: A reference to a location at which the other resource is found. The reference may a relative reference, in which case it is relative to the service base URL, or an absolute URL that resolves to the location where the resource is found. The reference may be version specific or not. If the reference is not to a FHIR RESTful server, then it should be assumed to be version specific. Internal fragment references (start with '#') refer to contained resources
annotation.comment:
Using absolute URLs provides a stable scalable approach suitable for a cloud/web context, while using relative/logical references provides a flexible approach suitable for use when trading across closed eco-system boundaries.
Absolute URLs do not need to point to a FHIR RESTful server, though this is the preferred approach. If the url conforms to the structure "/[type]/@[id]" then it should be assumed that the reference is to a FHIR RESTful server

annotation.definition: Plain text narrative that identifies the resource in addition to the resource reference
annotation.comment: This is generally not the same as the Resource.text of the referenced resource. The purpose is to identify what's being referenced, not to fully describe it.

invariant.human: Must have a local reference if the resource is provided inline
Must have a type if a reference is provided

annotations.shortDefinition: A series of measurements taken by a device
annotations.definition: A series of measurements taken by a device, with upper and lower limits. There may be more than one dimension in the data
annotations.comment: The data is not interpretable without at least origin, period, and dimensions, but these are optional to allow a separation between the template of measurement and the actual measurement, such as between DeviceCapabilities and DeviceLog
annotations.requirements: There is a need for a concise way to handle the data produced by devices that sample a physical state at a high frequency

annotation.definition: The base quantity that a measured value of zero represents. In addition, this provides the units of the entire measurement series
The length of time between sampling times, measured in milliseconds
annotation.comment: This is usually a whole number

annotation.shortDefinition: Multiply data by this before adding to origin
annotation.definition: A correction factor that is applied to the sampled data points before they are added to the origin
The lower limit of detection of the measured points. This is needed if any of the data points have the value "L" (lower than detection limit)
The upper limit of detection of the measured points. This is needed if any of the data points have the value "U" (higher than detection limit)

annotation.shortDefinition: Number of sample points at each time point
annotation.definition: The Number of sample points at each time point. If this value is greater than one, then the dimensions will be interlaced - all the sample points for a point in time will be recorded at once
annotation.comment: If there is more than one dimension, the code for the type of data will define the meaning of the dimensions (typically ECG data)

annotation.definition: A series of data points separated by a single space (character u20). The special values "E" (error), "L" (below detection limit) and "U" (above detection limit) can also be used

annotations.shortDefinition: A schedule that specifies an event that may occur multiple times
annotations.definition: A schedule that specifies an event that may occur multiple times. Schedules are not used for recording when things did happen, but when they are expected or requested to occur.
annotations.comment: A schedule can be either a list of events - intervals on which the event occurs, or a single event with repeating criteria or just repeating criteria with no actual event.
annotations.requirements: Need to able to track schedules. There are several different ways to do scheduling: one or more specified times, a simple rules like three times a day, or to say, x before/after meals, or something like that

annotations.definition: A nested type in Schedule: Identifies a repeating pattern to the intended time periods.

annotation.shortDefinition: Event occurs frequency times per duration
annotation.definition: Indicates how often the event should occur.

annotation.shortDefinition: Event occurs duration from common life event
annotation.definition: Identifies the occurrence of daily life that determine timing
annotation.requirements: Timings are frequently determined by occurrences such as waking, eating and sleep

annotation.definition: How long each repetition should last
annotation.requirements: Some activities are not instantaneous and need to be maintained for a period of time

annotation.shortDefinition: The units of time for the duration
annotation.definition: The units of time for the duration
A total count of the desired number of repetitions
annotation.comment: An end need not be specified
annotation.requirements: Repetitions may be limited by end time or total occurrences

annotation.definition: When to stop repeats
annotation.comment: An end need not be specified
annotation.requirements: Repetitions may be limited by end time or total occurrences

binding.name: UnitsOfTime
binding.definition: A unit of time (units from UCUM)

binding.name: EventTiming
binding.definition: A real world event that a schedule is related to

code.definition: event occurs [duration] before the hour of sleep (or trying to)
event occurs [duration] after waking
event occurs [duration] before a meal (from the Latin ante cibus)
event occurs [duration] before breakfast (from the Latin ante cibus matutinus)
event occurs [duration] before lunch (from the Latin ante cibus diurnus)
event occurs [duration] before dinner (from the Latin ante cibus vespertinus)
event occurs [duration] after a meal (from the Latin post cibus)
event occurs [duration] after breakfast (from the Latin post cibus matutinus)
event occurs [duration] after lunch (from the Latin post cibus diurnus)
event occurs [duration] after dinner (from the Latin post cibus vespertinus)

annotation.definition: Identifies specific time periods when the event should occur

annotation.definition: May be used to represent additional information that is not part of the basic definition of the resource. In order to make the use of extensions safe and manageable, there is a strict governance applied to the definition and use of extensions. Though any implementer is allowed to define an extension, there is a set of requirements that must be met as part of the definition of the extension
annotation.comment: there can be no stigma associated with the use of extensions by any application, project, or standard - regardless of the institution or jurisdiction that uses or defines the extensions. The use of extensions is what allows the FHIR specification to retain a core simplicity for everyone

annotation.definition: The base language in which the resource is written
annotation.comment:
Language is provided to support indexing and accessibility (typically, services such as text to speech use the language tag). The html language tag in the narrative applies to the narrative. The language tag on the resource may be used to specify the language of other presentations generated from the data in the resource
Not all the content has to be in the base language. The Resource.language should not be assumed to apply to the narrative automatically. If a language is specified, it should it also be specified on the div element in the html (see rules in HTML5 for information about the relationship between xml:lang and the html lang attribute)

annotation.shortDefinition: Text summary of the resource, for human interpretation
annotation.definition: A human readable narrative that contains a summary of the resource, and may be used to represent the content of the resource to a human. The narrative need not encode all the structured data, but is required to contain sufficient detail to make it "clinically safe" for a human to just read the narrative. Resource definitions may define what content should be represented in the narrative to ensure clinical safety
annotation.comment: Contained resources do not have narrative. Resources that are not contained SHOULD have a narrative

annotation.definition: These resources do not have an independent existence apart from the resource that contains them - they cannot be identified independently, and nor can they have their own independent transaction scope
annotation.comment: This should never be done when the content can be identified properly, as once identification is lost, it is extremely difficult (and context dependent) to restore it again

invariant.human: If the resource is contained in another resource, it SHALL not contain nexted Resources
If the resource is contained in another resource, it SHALL not contain any narrative

annotations.shortDefinition: Healthcare plan for patient
annotations.definition: Describes the intention of how one or more practitioners intend to deliver care for a particular patient for a period of time, possibly limited to care for a specific condition or set of conditions.
annotations.committeeNotes: At present, this resource combines the concepts of CarePlan and CareTeam. Should they be split?

annotations.definition: A nested type in CarePlan: Describes the intended objective(s) of carrying out the Care Plan.

annotation.definition: Human readable description of a specific desired objective of the care plan.
annotation.requirements: Without a description of what's trying to be achieved, element has no purpose

annotation.definition: Indicates whether the goal has been reached and is still considered relevant
annotation.requirements: Allows measuring outcome and also indicates relevance of goal to plan.

annotation.definition: Any comments related to the goal
annotation.comment: May be used for progress notes, concerns or other related information that doesn't actually describe the goal itself.
annotation.requirements: There's a need to capture information about the goal that doesn't actually describe the goal.

annotations.definition: A nested type in CarePlan: Identifies all people and organizations who are expected to be involved in the care envisioned by this plan.

annotation.definition: Indicates specific responsibility of an individual within the care plan. E.g. "Primary physician", "Team coordinator", "Caregiver", etc.
annotation.comment: Roles may sometimes be inferred by type of Practitioner. These are relationships that hold only within the context of the care plan. General relationships should be handled as properties of the Patient resource directly.

annotation.definition: The specific person or organization who is participating/expected to participate in the care plan.
annotation.comment: Patient only needs to be listed if they have a role other than "subject of care"
annotation.v2Mapping: REL.5 (or PRT-5-participation person : ( PRV-4 e {provider participations} ) / PRT-5-participation person : ( PRV-4 e {non-provider person participations} ) / PRT-5-participation person : ( PRV-4 = (patient non-subject of care) ) / PRT-8-participation organization?)

annotations.definition: A nested type in CarePlan: Identifies a planned action to occur as part of the plan. For example, a medication to be used, lab tests to perform, self-monitoring, education, etc.

annotation.definition: High-level categorization of the type of activity in a care plan.
annotation.requirements: May determine what types of extensions are permitted
annotation.committeeNotes: Should this be an HL7-defined code? Do we need more (e.g. accomodation)

annotation.definition: Detailed description of the type of activity. E.g. What lab test, what procedure, what kind of encounter.
annotation.comment: Tends to be less relevant for activities involving particular products. Codes should not convey negation - use "prohibited" instead.
annotation.requirements: Allows matching performed to planned as well as validation against protocols
annotation.v2Mapping: OBR-4-universal service ID / RXE-2-Give Code / RXO-1-Requested Give Code / RXD-2-Dispense/Give Code

annotation.shortDefinition: not started | ongoing | suspended | completed | abandoned
annotation.definition: Identifies what progress is being made for the specific activity.
annotation.comment: Some aspects of Status can be inferred based on the resources linked in actionTaken. Note that "status" is only as current as the plan was most recently updated.
annotation.requirements: Indicates progress against the plan, whether the activity is still relevant for the plan

annotation.definition: If true, indicates that the described activity is one that must NOT be engaged in when following the plan.
annotation.requirements: Captures intention to not do something that may have been previously typical.

annotation.definition: The period, timing or frequency upon which the described activity is to occur.
annotation.requirements: Allows prompting for activities and detection of missed planned activities.

annotation.definition: Identifies the facility where the activity will occur. E.g. home, hospital, specific clinic, etc.
annotation.comment: May reference a specific clinical location or may just identify a type of location.
annotation.requirements: Helps in planning of activity

annotation.definition: Identifies who's expected to be involved in the activity.
annotation.requirements: Helps in planning of activity
annotation.v2Mapping: PRT-5-participation person : ( PRV-4 e {provider participations} ) / PRT-5-participation person : ( PRV-4 e {non-provider person participations} ) / PRT-5-participation person : ( PRV-4 = (patient non-subject of care) ) / PRT-8-participation organization

annotation.definition: Identifies the food, drug or other product being consumed or supplied in the activity.
annotation.v2Mapping: RXE-2-Give Code / RXO-1-Requested Give Code / RXD-2-Dispense/Give Code

annotation.definition: Identifies the quantity expected to be consumed in a given day.
annotation.requirements: Allows rough dose checking
annotation.v2Mapping: RXO-23-total daily dose / RXE-19-total daily dose / RXD-12-total daily dose

annotation.definition: Identifies the quantity expected to be supplied.
annotation.v2Mapping: RXO-11-requested dispense amount / RXE-10-dispense amount / RXD-4-actual dispense amount / RXG-5-give amount-minumum / RXA-6-administered amount / TQ1-2.1-quantity.quantity *and* RXO-12-requested dispense units / RXE-11-dispense units / RXD-5-actual dispense units / RXG-7-give units / RXA-7-administered units / TQ1-2.2-quantity.units

annotation.definition: This provides a textual description of constraints on the activity occurrence, including relation to other activities. It may also include objectives, pre-conditions and end-conditions. Finally, it may convey specifics about the activity such as body site, method, route, etc.
Resources that describe follow-on actions resulting from the plan, such as drug prescriptions, encounter records, appointments, etc.
annotation.requirements: Links plan to resulting actions

annotation.definition: Notes about the execution of the activity
annotation.comment: Doesn't describe the activity - that goes in details.
annotation.requirements: Can be used to capture information about adherence, progress, concerns, etc.

binding.name: CarePlanActivityCode
binding.definition: Detailed description of the type of activity. E.g. What lab test, what procedure, what kind of encounter.

binding.name: CarePlanStatus
binding.definition: Indicates whether the plan is currently being acted upon, represents future intentions or is now just historical record.

code.definition: The plan is in development or awaiting use but is not yet intended to be acted upon.
The plan is intended to be followed and used as part of patient care
The plan is no longer in use and is not expected to be followed or used in patient care

binding.name: CarePlanActivityCategory
binding.definition: High-level categorization of the type of activity in a care plan.

code.definition: Plan for the patient to consume food of a specified nature
Plan for the patient to consume/receive a drug, vaccine or other product
Plan to meet or communicate with the patient (in-patient, out-patient, phone call, etc.)
Plan to capture information about a patient (vitals, labs, diagnostic images, etc.)
Plan to modify the patient in some way (surgery, physio-therapy, education, counselling, etc.)
Plan to provide something to the patient (medication, medical supply, etc.)
Some other form of action

binding.name: CarePlanGoalStatus
binding.definition: Indicates whether the goal has been met and is still being targeted

code.definition: The goal is being sought but has not yet been reached. (Also applies if goal was reached in the past but there has been regression and goal is being sought again)
The goal has been met and no further action is needed
The goal has been met, but ongoing activity is needed to sustain the goal objective
The goal is no longer being sought

binding.name: CarePlanParticipantRole
binding.definition: Indicates specific responsibility of an individual within the care plan. E.g. "Primary physician", "Team coordinator", "Caregiver", etc.

binding.name: CarePlanActivityStatus
binding.definition: Indicates where the activity is at in its overall life cycle

code.definition: Activity is planned but no action has yet been taken
Appointment or other booking has occurred but activity has not yet begun
Activity has been started but is not yet complete
Activity was started but has temporarily ceased with an expectation of resumption at a future time.
The activities have been completed (more or less) as planned
The activities have been ended prior to completion (perhaps even before they were started)

annotation.definition: Unique identifier by which the care plan is known in different business contexts.
Identifies the patient/subject whose intended care is described by the plan.
annotation.requirements: Care plans must be associated with the patient the plan is for.

annotation.definition: Indicates whether the plan is currently being acted upon, represents future intentions or is now just historical record.
annotation.requirements: Allows clinicians to determine whether the plan is actionable or not

annotation.definition: Indicates when the plan did (or is intended to) come into effect and end.
annotation.comment: Any activities scheduled as part of the plan should be constrained to the specified period.
annotation.requirements: Allows tracking what plan(s) are in effect at a particular time.
annotation.v2Mapping: GOL-7-goal established date/time / GOL-8-expected goal achieve date/time

annotation.definition: Identifies the most recent date on which the plan has been revised.
annotation.requirements: Indicates how current the plan is.
annotation.v2Mapping: PTH-6-change pathway life cycle status date/time
annotation.committeeNotes: Do we need this in addition to the resouce metadata which tracks last changed?

annotation.definition: Identifies the conditions/problems/concerns/diagnoses/etc. whose management and/or mitigation are handled by this plan.
annotation.requirements: Links plan to the conditions it manages. Also scopes plans - multiple plans may exist addressing different concerns.

annotation.definition: Identifies all people and organizations who are expected to be involved in the care envisioned by this plan.
annotation.requirements: Allows representation of care teams, helps scope care plan. In some cases may be a determiner of access permissions.
annotation.v2Mapping: REL (REL.4 is always the Patient) ( or PRT?)

annotation.definition: Describes the intended objective(s) of carrying out the Care Plan.
annotation.comment: Goal can be achieving a particular change or merely maintaining a current state or even slowing a decline.
annotation.requirements: Provides context for plan. Allows plan effectiveness to be evaluated by clinicians.
annotation.committeeNotes: Should this be expanded into code + value + timeframe?

annotation.shortDefinition: Action to occur as part of plan
annotation.definition: Identifies a planned action to occur as part of the plan. For example, a medication to be used, lab tests to perform, self-monitoring, education, etc.
annotation.requirements: Allows systems to prompt for performance of planned activities, validate plans against best practice.

annotation.definition: General notes about the care plan not covered elsewhere
annotation.requirements: Used to capture information that applies to the plan as a whole that doesn't fit into discrete elements.

example.name: Integrated
example.description: Simple integrated care plan with multiple goals & conditions (from Mayo)

search.description: [CarePlan.period] contains date

annotations.shortDefinition: Detailed information about conditions, problems or diagnoses
annotations.definition: Use to record detailed information about conditions, problems or diagnoses recognized by a clinician. There are many uses including: recording a Diagnosis during a Encounter; populating a problem List or a Summary Statement, such as a Discharge Summary

a text like "in their teens". => new ballot comment.

* Change the description: it is circular

Target of the relationship

code.definition: This is a tentative diagnosis - still a candidate that is under consideration
The patient is being treated on the basis that this is the condition, but it is still not confirmed

This condition has been ruled out by diagnostic and clinical evidence

binding.definition: A subjective assessment of the severity of the condition as evaluated by the clinician.

annotation.definition: Encounter during which the condition was first asserted
Person who takes responsibility for asserting the existence of the condition as part of the electronic record
Estimated or actual date the condition/problem/diagnosis was first detected/suspected

annotation.shortDefinition: Identification of the condition, problem or diagnosis
annotation.definition: Identification of the condition, problem or diagnosis.
A category assigned to the condition. E.g. finding | Condition | diagnosis | concern | condition
annotation.comment: The categorization is often highly contextual and may appear poorly differentiated or not very useful in other contexts
annotation.v2Mapping: 'problem' if from PRB-3. 'diagnosis' if from DG1 segment in PV1 message

annotation.definition: The clinical status of the condition
The degree of confidence that this condition is correct
annotation.comment: May be a percentage

annotation.definition: A subjective assessment of the severity of the condition as evaluated by the clinician.
annotation.comment: Coding of the severity with a terminology is preferred, where possible

annotation.shortDefinition: Estimated or actual date, or age
annotation.definition: Estimated or actual date the condition began, in the opinion of the clinician
annotation.comment: Age is generally used when the patient reports an age at which the Condition began to occur

annotation.definition: The date or estimated date that the condition resolved or went into remission. This is called "abatement" because of the many overloaded connotations associated with "remission" or "resolution" - Conditions are never really resolved, but they can abate.
annotation.comment:
There is no explicit distinction between resolution and remission because in many cases the distinction is not clear. Age is generally used when the patient reports an age at which the Condition abated.
If there is no abatement element, it is unknown whether the condition has resolved or entered remission; applications and users should generally assume that the condition is still valid

annotation.definition: Clinical stage or grade of a condition. May include formal severity assessments
Supporting Evidence / manfiestions that are the basis on which this condition is suspected or confirmed
annotation.comment: The evidence may be a simple lost of coded symptoms/manifestations, or references to observations or formal assessments, or both

annotation.definition: The anatomical location where this condition manifests itself
annotation.comment: May be a summary code, or a reference to a very precise definition of the location, or both

annotation.shortDefinition: Causes or precedents for this Condition
annotation.definition: Further conditions, problems, diagnoses, procedures or events that are related in some way to this condition, or the substance that caused/triggered this Condition
annotation.comment: Although a condition may be caused by a substance, this is not intended to be used to record allergies/adverse reactions to substances
annotation.v2Mapping: could infer from presence of multiple PRB segments in a PPR message that the problems are related, but not clear how to communicate the nature of the relationship

annotation.definition: Additional information about the Condition. This is a general notes/comments entry for description of the Condition, it's diagnosis and prognosis
annotation.todo: Definition needs checking

annotation.definition: Identifies the resource exposed via the restful interface
Identifies the profile that describes the solution's support for the resource, including any constraints on cardinality, bindings, lengths or other limitations
annotation.comment: This profile applies to all the resources of this type - i.e. it is the superset of what is supported
annotation.todo: Does a system need to be able to enumerate profiles that it doe support?

annotation.definition: Identifies a restful operation supported by the solution
annotation.comment: The 'search' operation is handled separately

annotation.shortDefinition: Whether vRead can return past versions
annotation.definition: A flag for whether the server is able to return past versions as part of the vRead operation
annotation.comment: It is useful to support the vRead operation for current operations, even if past versions aren't available

annotation.definition: _include values supported by the server
annotation.comment: If this list is empty, the server does not support includes

annotation.definition: Defines additional search parameters for implementations to support and/or make use of

annotations.definition: A nested type in Conformance: Used when the statement describes the capabilities of a specific implementation instance - i.e. a particular installation, rather than the capabilities of a software program

annotation.definition: Information about the specific installation that this conformance statement relates to
The base URL for the implementation. This forms the base for REST interfaces as well as the mailbox and document interfaces.

annotations.definition: A nested type in Conformance: Identifies a restful operation supported by the solution

annotation.definition: Identifies which operation is supported

Provides guidance specific to the implementation of this operation, such as 'delete is a logical delete' or 'updates are only allowed with version id' or 'creates permitted from pre-authorized certificates only'
annotation.requirements: REST allows a degree of variability in the implementation of RESTful solutions that is useful for exchange partners to be aware of.

annotations.definition: A nested type in Conformance: Describes the solution's support for an event at this end point.

annotation.definition: Identifies the supported messaging event
annotation.todo: May need profile id as well if profiles can define message events

annotation.definition: The mode of this event declaration - whether application is sender or receiver
Identifies the messaging transport protocol(s) supported by this endpoint
annotation.todo: Loosen this to "extensible" once tooling supports that.

annotation.definition: Identifies the resource associated with the event. This is the resource that defines the event.
annotation.comment: This must be provided if the event type supports multiple different resource types

annotation.definition: Information about the request for this event
Information about the response for this event
Guidance on how this event is handled, such as internal system trigger points, business rules, etc.

annotations.definition: A nested type in Conformance: Information about security of implementation

annotation.shortDefinition: What type of security services are supported/required
annotation.definition: What type of security services are supported/required

annotation.shortDefinition: General description of how security works
annotation.definition: General description of how security works
Certificates associated with security profiles

annotations.definition: A nested type in Conformance: Certificates associated with security profiles

annotation.definition: Mime type for certificate
Actual certificate

annotations.definition: A nested type in Conformance: Defines additional search parameters for implementations to support and/or make use of

annotation.definition: Corresponds to the name of the standard or custom search parameter
annotation.comment: Parameter names cannot overlap with standard parameter names, and standard parameters cannot be redefined

annotation.definition: A formal reference to where this parameter was first defined, so that a client can be confident of the meaning of the search parameter
annotation.comment: This SHOULD be populated for all search parameters not defined as custom search extensions. The uri for a search parameter defined in the specification itself is http://hl7.org/fhir/[resource]/search#[name]

annotation.definition: The type of value a search parameter refers to, and how the content is interpreted

annotation.shortDefinition: Contents and meaning of search parameter
annotation.definition: For standard parameters, provides additional information on how the parameter is used in this solution. For custom parameters, provides a description of what the parameter does

annotation.shortDefinition: XPath that extracts the parameter set
annotation.definition: An XPath expression that extracts the set of elements that contain values that a search parameter matches
annotation.comment: Note that the elements are sometimes complex elements where logic is required to determine quite how to handle them. E.g. CodeableConcepts may contain text and/or multiple codings, where the codings themselves contain a code and a system

annotation.shortDefinition: Types of resource (if a resource reference)
annotation.definition: Types of resource (if a resource reference)
Chained names supported

binding.name: RestfulOperation
binding.definition: Operations supported by REST

code.definition: Read the current state of the resource
Read the state of a specific version of the resource
Update an existing resource by its id (or create it if it is new)
Delete a resource
Retrieve the update history for a resource instance
Check that the content would be acceptable as an update
Get a list of updates to resources of this type
Create a new resource with a server assigned id
Supports search operations using the parameters described in the profile
Transaction performed on multiple resources
Get a list of updates to all resources on the system

binding.name: DocumentMode
binding.definition: Whether the application produces or consumes documents

code.definition: The application produces documents of the specified type
The application consumes documents of the specified type

binding.name: RestfulConformanceMode
binding.definition: The mode of a restful conformance statement

code.definition: The application acts as a server for this resource
The application acts as a client for this resource

binding.name: MessageTransport
binding.definition: How messages are delivered

code.definition: The application sends or receives messages using HTTP POST (may be over http or https)
The application sends or receives messages using File Transfer Protocol
The application sends or receivers messages using HL7's Minimal Lower Level Protocol

binding.name: ConformanceEventMode
binding.definition: The mode of a message conformance statement

code.definition: The application sends requests and receives responses
The application receives requests and sends responses

binding.name: ConformanceStatementStatus
binding.definition: The status of this conformance statement

code.definition: This conformance statement is still under development
This conformance statement is ready for use in production systems
This conformance statement has been withdrawn or superceded and should no longer be used

binding.name: SearchParamType
binding.definition: Data types allowed to be used for search parameters

code.definition: Search parameter must be a simple whole number

Search parameter is a simple string, like a name part. Search is case-insensitive and accent-insensitive. May match just the start of a string. String parameters may contain spaces and are delineated by double quotes, e.g. "van Zanten".

Search parameter is on a long string. Used for text filter type search: it functions on searches within a body of text and may contain spaces to separate words. May match even if the separate words are found out of order. Text parameters are delineated by double quotes.
Search parameter is on a date (and should support :before and :after modifiers). The date format is the standard XML format, though other formats may be supported

Search parameter on a coded element or identifier. May be used to search through the text, displayname, code and code/codesystem (for codes) and label, system and key (for identifier). It's value is either a string or a pair of namespace and value, separated by a "/", depending on the modifier used

A pair of resource type and resource id, separated by "/". Matches when the resource reference resolves to a resource of the given type and id. The resource type may be omitted to search all types if used with the modifier :any
A composite search parameter that combines other search parameters together

binding.name: RestfulSecurityService
binding.definition: Types of security services used with FHIR

code.definition: OAuth (see oauth.net)
OAuth version 2 (see oauth.net)
Microsoft NTLM Authentication
Basic authentication defined in HTTP specification

annotation.shortDefinition: Logical id to reference this statement
annotation.definition: The identifier that is used to identify this conformance statement when it is referenced in a specification, model, design or an instance (should be globally unique OID, UUID, or URI)

annotation.shortDefinition: Logical id for this version of the statement
annotation.definition: The identifier that is used to identify this version of the conformance statement when it is referenced in a specification, model, design or instance. This is an arbitrary value managed by the profile author manually and the value should be a timestamp
annotation.comment: There may be multiple resource versions of the conformance statement that have this same identifier

annotation.shortDefinition: Informal name for this conformance statement
annotation.definition: A free text natural language name identifying the conformance statement
annotation.comment: Not expected to be globally unique

annotation.definition: Name of Organization
Contacts for Organization relevant to this conformance statement. May be website, email, phone numbers, etc.

annotation.shortDefinition: Human description of the conformance statement
annotation.definition: A free text natural language description of the conformance statement and its use. Typically, thsis is used when the profile describes a desired rather than an actual solution, for example as a formal expression of requirements as part of an RFP
annotation.comment: This field can be used for things such as why the confomrance statement was written, comments about it's context etc. This does not need to be populated when the description is adequately implied by the software or implementation details

annotation.shortDefinition: draft | experimental | review | production | withdrawn | superseded
annotation.definition: The status of this conformance statement
annotation.comment: This is not intended for use with actual conformance statements, but where conformance statements are used to describe possible or desired systems

annotation.shortDefinition: If for testing purposes, not real usage
annotation.definition: This conformance statement was authored for testing purposes (or education/evaluation/marketing), and is not intended to be used for genuine usage
annotation.comment: Allows filtering of conformance statements that are appropriate for use vs. not

annotation.definition: Date that the conformance statement is published

annotation.shortDefinition: Software that is covered by this conformance statement
annotation.definition: Describes the software that is covered by this conformance statement. Used when the profile describes the capabilities of a particular software version, independent of an installation.

annotation.shortDefinition: If this describes a specific instance
annotation.definition: Used when the statement describes the capabilities of a specific implementation instance - i.e. a particular installation, rather than the capabilities of a software program
The version of the FHIR specification on which this conformance statement is based

annotation.shortDefinition: True if application accepts unknown elements
annotation.definition: Whether the application accepts unknown non-"must understand" elements as part of a resource. This does not include extensions, but genuine new additions to a resource
The formats supported by this implementation
annotation.comment: "xml" or "json" are allowed, which describe the simple encodings described in the specification (and imply appropriate bundle support). Otherwise, mime types are legal here

annotation.shortDefinition: If the endpoint is a RESTful one
annotation.definition: Defines the restful capabilities of the solution, if any
annotation.comment: Multiple repetitions allow definition of both client and server behaviors or possibly behaviors under different configuration settings (for software or requirements statements)

annotation.definition: Describes the messaging capabilities of the solution
annotation.comment: Multiple repetitions allow the documentation of multiple endpoints per solution

annotation.definition: A document definition

invariant.human: Must have at least one of description, software, or implementation
A Conformance profile must have at least one of rest, messaging or document

search.description: the conformance statement publication date

search.name: mode

search.description: the version of FHIR

annotations.shortDefinition: Insurance or medical plan
annotations.definition: Financial instrument by which payment information for health care
annotations.requirements: Health care programs and insurers are significant payors of health service costs

annotations.definition: A nested type in Coverage: Planholder information

annotation.definition: The name of the PolicyHolder
annotation.requirements: Used to validate coverage

annotation.definition: The mailing address, typically home, of the PolicyHolder
The date of birth of the PolicyHolder
annotation.requirements: Used to validate coverage

binding.name: CoverageType
binding.definition: The type of insurance: public health, worker compensation; private accident, auto, private health, etc.)

annotation.shortDefinition: An identifier for the plan issuer
annotation.definition: The program or plan underwriter or payor.
annotation.requirements: Need to identify the issuer to target for processing and for coordination of benefit processing.

annotation.definition: Time period during which the coverage is in force. A missing start date indicates the start date isn't known, a missing end date means the coverage is continuing to be in force.
annotation.v2Mapping: IN1-12-plan effective date / IN1-13-plan expiration date

annotation.definition: The type of coverage: social program, medical plan, accident coverage (workers compensation, auto), group health.
annotation.requirements: The order of application of coverages is dependent on the types of coverage.

annotation.definition: The main (and possibly only) identifier for the coverage - often referred to as a Subscriber Id, Certificate number or Personal Health Number or Case ID.
annotation.requirements: This value may uniquely identify the coverage or it may be used in conjunction with the additional identifiers below.

annotation.definition: Identifies a style or collective of coverage issues by the underwriter, for example may be used to identify a class of coverage or employer group. May also be referred to as a Policy or Group ID.

annotation.shortDefinition: An identifier for the subsection of the plan
annotation.definition: Identifies a sub-style or sub-collective of coverage issues by the underwriter, for example may be used to identify a specific employer group within a class of employers. May be referred to as a Section or Division ID.
A unique identifier for a dependent under the coverage.
annotation.requirements: For some coverage a single identifier is issued to the PolicyHolder and dependent number issues to each to each of their dependents to track and manage the plan.
annotation.v2Mapping: - No exact V2.x equivalent concept seems to exist; instance relationship can be inferred if ( ( PID-3-patient ID list IN1-49-insured's ID number ) & ( IN2-72-patient's relationship to insured ) )

annotation.shortDefinition: The plan instance or sequence counter
annotation.definition: An optional counter for a particular instance of the identified coverage which increments upon each renewal.
annotation.requirements: Some coverage, for example social plans, may be offered in short time increments, for example for a week or a month at a time, so while the rest of the plan details and identifiers may remain constant over time, the instance is incremented with each renewal and provided to the covered party on their 'card'.
annotation.v2Mapping: No V2.x equivalent concept seems to exist

annotation.definition: Planholder information

annotations.shortDefinition: An instance of a manufactured thing that is used in the provision of healthcare
annotations.definition: This resource identifies an instance of a manufactured thing that is used in the provision of healthcare without being substantially changed through that activity. The device may be a machine, an insert, a computer, an application, etc. This includes durable (reusable) medical equipment as well as disposable equipment used for diagnostic, treatment, and research for healthcare and public health.
annotations.requirements: Allows institutions to track their devices.

annotations.definition: A nested type in Device: Universal Device Id fields

annotation.definition: The number assigned to this device by an authorised issuer of Device GTINs, based on the standards set by GS1
annotation.comment: This is a 14 digit number that may include leading 0s

annotation.definition: Lot number of manufacture
annotation.comment: Alphanumeric Maximum 20

annotation.shortDefinition: Serial number assigned by the manufacturer
annotation.definition: The serial number assigned by the organisation when the device was manufactured
annotation.comment: Alphanumeric Maximum 20

binding.name: DeviceKind
binding.definition: Defines the nature of the device and the kind of functionality/services/behavior that may be expected from it

annotation.shortDefinition: What kind of device this is
annotation.definition: Describes what kind of device that this
The name of the manufacturer

annotation.shortDefinition: Model id assigned by the manufacturer
annotation.definition: The "model" - an identifier assigned by the manufacturer to identify the product by it's type. This number is shared by the all devices sold as the same type
The version of the device, if the device has multiple releases under the same model, or if the device is software or carries firmware

annotation.shortDefinition: Date of expiry of this device (if applicable)
annotation.definition: Date of expiry of this device (if applicable)
Universal Device Id fields
annotation.requirements: In order to carry UDI (US regulations, but being adopted across the world)

annotation.definition: The organization that is responsible for the provision and ongoing maintenance of the device
Identifiers assigned to this device by various organizations (unless other specific fields exist for them)
annotation.comment: Often fixed to the device as a barcode. May include names given to the device in local usage

annotation.definition: The resource may be found in a literal location (i.e. GPS coordinates), a logical place (i.e. "in/with the patient"), or a coded location

annotation.shortDefinition: If the resource is affixed to a person
annotation.definition: If the resource is affixed to a person
Contact details for an organization or a particular human that is responsible for the device
annotation.comment: used for troubleshooting etc.

annotation.definition: A network address on which the device may be contacted directly
annotation.comment: if the device is running a FHIR server, the network address should be the root URL from which a conformance statement may be retrieved

search.name: organization
search.description: the organization responsible for the device

search.description: the model of the device

search.description: The logical resource id associated with the resource (must be supported by all servers)

search.description: Where the resource is found

search.description: the manufacturer of the device

search.description: identifier assigned by the organisation

search.description: the type of the device

search.description: the serial number of the device

binding.definition: The type of data produced by a device

code.definition: The data item is a quantity. The string value should be merged with the units, and the ucum value if provided, to create a valid quantity
The data item is a range. The string value should be split about the " - " into low and high, with the units and ucum (if provided) filling out the low and high quantities
The data item is a code (i.e. true/false etc). The value should be built into a valid coding by filling out the system element provided
The data item is an Array (a sequence of sample measures, which must be merged with the Array template)
The data item is a simple string
